Mathematically it can be expressed like this : $$ P = E_{\text{ single}} \times N$$We know that one watt equals to joule/second so we have for our case where MW stands fo megawatt which equal million watts(or$*10{}^6$) W): \[ {10}^8\ J/{s} =(energy releasedpernuclearevent)\cdot\(numberofeventsinasecond).\]The average total kinetic energy released in fission of uranium nucleus is about ${200 MeV}$ . This value includes both the instantenous kinetic energy of all fragments, and also the heat and other forms of energy produced in the process of cooling down the remnants of the original nucleus. Now ,we convert mega electron volt into Joules using following relation:${\small 1 eV=1.6}\times{10}^{-19}{\small J }$ then ${\small 200MeV=(200)(1.6}\times{10}^{-19})=3.2\times{10^{-17}}{\small J }$. So now plugging these values back intotheequation above we get\[ ({3.2 }\times{10}^{−17}{J})·N={10}^8\,.\]And thus,\[N=\frac{{10}^8}{{3.2 }{10}^{-17}}=3.{10}^{25}.\]So option $\boxed{(d)}$ i correct
